More than three years ago I was at your position, but I wasn't free for some extent due to I ought to study C++ due to an academic course. 

After that I searched online, how best universities around the world put their students at the begin of programming way. And I found two schools here out: 

1- Some says that the best start point is to start with (Python) "Which is very closed to Ruby, so they thought as you did precisely". At the top of universities who follow this track you will find Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) the best university in mathematical applications around the world, and here is the introductory course they study: http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-189-a-gentle-introduction-to-programming-using-python-january-iap-2011/

2- Another approach is to start with (C++) "or sometimes C". And at the top of universities who follow this track you will find Stanford University the best university in Artificial intelligence and Algorithmic applications around the world. but I can't find it online yet. 

I like the second approach more, may be because I forced to follow it and found it interesting and useful. But the main reason is that you will need to learn more programming languages later such as Java, C#, JavaScript and/or PHP. And C++ syntactically is more similar to these languages' syntax than Ruby or Python. 

But a very helpful fact that you should recognise before starting is that you will need to learn almost all of these programming languages: http://www.quora.com/What-programming-languages-should-a-modern-day-programmer-have-in-his-her-arsenal

Finally, if you are a computer science student, I think you should master this course before learning any programming language. It's a self study introductory course to the computer science with no deadlines as a field and which you will face in your extremely interesting and informative journey: https://class.coursera.org/cs101-selfservice.

Hope it's helpful, and if there are any other questions I'm in demand :)

أتوقع البوست بتاعك اتمسح، و البوست ده كمان ممكن يتمسح (أنا كأدمن موافق لو نفس الأدمن اللي مسح اللي فات عايز يمسح ده كمان)، لإن السؤال من أنواع الأسئلة اللي الصفحة هنا بتتجنبها. مافيش حاجة اسمها ايه رأيكم في الروبي. كله شغال.

هنا مش مكان سؤال المبتدئين العام، و خصوصا مش مكان ايه رأيكم أشتغل بروبي ولا لأ. فيه ألف جروب للكلام ده على فيسبوك.الجروب ده حريص ما يبقاش الألف وواحد و يبقى مكان أنسب لأسئلة و مواضيع المحترفين اللي ليها معنى و إجابة.

أنا أسف من سخافة الرد لكن لزم التوضيح.
Dude it was a joke and the guy asked a valid question. the group called egyptian geeks not egyptian software professionals. Have a good day full of fun  :)

Mohamed Meligy I did know this was a joke. I think the idea here is to try to explain to people that technologies are all valid and useful, so we need to focus on the right place and time to uuse each one instead of having the repetitive religious debate. The reason I knew it was a joke is because you said we don't like language wars unless they involved Ruby or Python, so he just played along with that

I think this is valid as a joke. Apparently I and some other admin did not see it that way. If anyone thinks this is a valid serious question and thinks the group is not particularly for experienced professionals, read the "About" section of the group please (which is not something new BTW).

Actually, after another thought. Obviously several people replying didn't think it was a joke and replied seriously. That's why the warning is still important, although I take back my opinion for deleting the post, because as I said, it's valid as a joke (a very practical one that several commenters fell for!).

Well the group is called Egyptian "Geeks" and as the namesake implies, we are geeks i.e. people who love and enjoy technology, we don't necessarily have to be gurus or experts, but what brings us together is a love of learning. Some geeks are new at some things and experts at others. The idea of "experienced professionals" is more at odds with the word "geek" cause a geek does not have to be a professional (make money out of his geekdom), but rather someone who does things for the fun of it. And geeks usually have odd sense of humors, which is why we have to be more accomodating. As for not starting an "Us vs Them", I totally agree and understand that the message has been made clear, I was even one of the people relaying it.

from while you asked about marketing course and I recommended some links. Go to it and check something called customer need.
I think that is what happening here.
Mohamed Amgad usually "Marketing" is a "dirty word " in geek circles :) but as I said we have to be accomodating
